description.summary: Supernatural beings from Celtic and European folklore, often small humanoid creatures with magical powers. The Fae Folk inhabit a parallel realm and interact with humans in complex, sometimes dangerous ways.
description.full: Fairies (also known as the Fae or Sidhe) are supernatural beings deeply rooted in Celtic mythology and European folklore. While often depicted in modern culture as tiny, winged, benevolent creatures, traditional fairy lore presents a far more complex and sometimes dangerous picture. The Fae are believed to be a separate race of supernatural beings, possibly remnants of ancient gods or nature spirits, who inhabit the Otherworld—a parallel realm that overlaps with our own. Fairy encounters often involve time distortion, enchantment, abduction, and the exchange of human children for changelings. Traditional Celtic cultures treated the Fae with great respect and caution, using euphemisms like 'Fair Folk' or 'Good Neighbors' to avoid offending them. Fairy belief spans from ancient pre-Christian traditions through medieval folklore to modern encounters and cultural revivals.

etymology.origin: From Old French 'faerie' (enchantment, magic), derived from Latin 'fata' (the Fates). Related to 'fay' and 'fey.' Irish 'Sidhe' refers to the ancient burial mounds where fairies were believed to dwell.
etymology.meaning: Enchanted beings; people of the otherworld; supernatural race

range.description: Fairy beliefs are found worldwide, but the specific Fae Folk tradition is most strongly associated with Celtic lands—Ireland, Scotland, Wales, Cornwall, Brittany, and the Isle of Man. Similar beings exist in most cultures under different names.

temporal.seasonal_patterns: Fairy activity peaks at liminal times: dusk, dawn, solstices, equinoxes. Samhain (Halloween) and Beltane (May Day) are especially significant.

origins.cultural_roots: Fairy belief has roots in pre-Christian Celtic religion, possibly representing memories of ancient gods (Tuatha Dé Danann), ancestors, or nature spirits. Some theories suggest folk memories of indigenous pre-Celtic peoples.
origins.earliest_accounts: Irish mythological cycles (Ulster Cycle, Fenian Cycle) from oral tradition transcribed by medieval monks. Welsh Mabinogion. Pre-Christian roots with medieval Christian overlay.
origins.folklore_connections: Connected to Indo-European divine beings, ancestral spirits, nature worship, and animistic beliefs. Shares characteristics with Norse elves, Germanic dwarves, and Slavic nature spirits.

history.modern_era: Contemporary fairy belief exists in several forms: cultural tradition in Celtic countries, Neo-pagan religious practice, folklore studies, and modern 'fairy sighting' reports. Ireland still has active fairy belief affecting land use decisions. Modern fantasy literature has created its own fairy tradition distinct from folklore.

notable.name: Rev. Robert Kirk Disappearance
notable.description: Rev. Robert Kirk, Episcopal minister and Gaelic scholar who wrote 'The Secret Commonwealth' about Scottish fairy beliefs, collapsed on Fairy Hill and died (or fell into coma). Local tradition holds he was taken by the fairies for revealing their secrets. He allegedly appeared to a relative after death, claiming to be held by the Fae.
evidence: Death on site associated with fairies

credibility.notes: Real person whose death spawned fairy legend. Whether natural death or something else remains unknown.

sources: Kirk, R. (1691). The Secret Commonwealth of Elves, Fauns and Fairies
Stewart, W.G. (1823). The Popular Superstitions of the Highlands

notable.name: Bridget Cleary Changeling Case
notable.description: 26-year-old Bridget Cleary fell ill. Her husband Michael and relatives became convinced she was a changeling and the real Bridget was held by fairies. They subjected her to 'fairy tests' including holding her over a fire to force the fairy to flee. Bridget died from burns and beatings. Michael and others were tried for manslaughter. The case became a scandal demonstrating persistence of fairy belief.

credibility.notes: Real case demonstrating belief in changelings persisted into late 19th century Ireland. Bridget was human; belief killed her.

sources: Bourke, A. (1999). The Burning of Bridget Cleary

notable.name: Cottingley Fairies Photographs

types: Children - Elsie Wright and Frances Griffiths

notable.description: Two young cousins, Elsie Wright (16) and Frances Griffiths (9), produced photographs appearing to show them with fairies. The images caused sensation when championed by Arthur Conan Doyle. In 1983, the women admitted the photos were faked using cardboard cutouts, though Frances maintained she really saw fairies.

credibility.notes: Famous hoax that fooled Conan Doyle and others. Significant for showing desire to believe in fairies persisted into modern era.

sources: Cooper, J. (1997). The Case of the Cottingley Fairies

indigenous.significance: Fairies are integral to Celtic cultural identity, representing connection to land, ancestors, and pre-Christian spirituality. Fairy belief influences land use, place names, and cultural practices in Celtic regions.
indigenous.sensitivity_note: Fairy traditions are living cultural heritage for Celtic peoples. While folklore is shared, spiritual practices (especially Neo-pagan) should be approached with respect for practitioners.
